subject: [Fwd: Shavian's origins]
messageBody:
"C. Paige Gabhart" wrote:

> Star:
>
> Thanks for the reply. First, a cautionary note: let me assure you that I am
> enjoying discussing these points with you and am just expressing my point of view
> in the following post. I am an attorney and am used to debating my point of view
> (or my client's) Many people seem to find the expression of a difference of
> opinion as somehow objectionable, but wouldn't it be a boring world if we were all
> required to hold to the same beliefs. When I express my views to you, this should
> not be taken to mean I deny your right to hold a different viewpoint
>
> Now on to your last post: I believe what you are remembering is that the the
> judges in the contest held as a result of Shaw's will named four winners.
> Kingsley Read was one of them. Russ DeMeyere's Shavian website quotes a letter
> from the Public Trustee which states: "Shaw imposed on his trustees the duty of
> seeking and publishing a more efficient alphabet of at least forty letters than
> the existing one of twenty-six letters to enable 'the said language to be written
> without indicating single sounds by groups of letters or by diacritical
> marks'...in the end a design by Mr. Kingsley Read was adopted to fulfill this and
> other terms of Bernard Shaw's will." (see www.demeyere.com/Shavian/info.html)
>
> Star Raven wrote:
>
> > I read somewhere that the final shaw alphabet was a conglomeration of
> > four designs to create the finished product, I never said shaw did it,
> > it was the money in HIS will.
>
> When Read developed Quikscript, he dropped the two separate characters for the
> pairs "Err" and "Array" and "Up" and "Ado" which appeared in Shavian. This was
> done after extensive correspondence in Shavian between English speaking countries
> around the world. I assume he decided that the distinction was not as clear as he
> first thought it was from his British perspective, and that it added a needless
> complexity to the alphabet. On the other hand, he added "Wh" to Quikscript, which
> he learned many people still do distinguish and feel quite strongly about it.
>
> I have not followed the discussion closely regarding stress, but if that is the
> primary distinction between "Ado" and "Up" and "Array" and "Err", then I believe
> Read was correct in dropping the "stressed" characters. I have been using
> Quikscript for over twenty-five years, and I have never missed "Err" or "Up". In
> fact, I was not sure what sounds they were supposed to represent as I could not
> hear any distinction in the way I pronounced the applicable words. It had never
> occurred to me that the difference was supposedly one of stress. My reaction is
> that certain vowels will be stressed as a result of where they appear in a given
> word and as a result of the consonants surrounding them. We do not have other
> letters whose only difference is stress, and I do not think stress should be
> represented by a different character in the alphabet.
>
> The dictionary I have here at home is Webster's Ninth New Collegiate. I looked up
> "Ado", "Up", "Array" and "Err", and the opening vowel sound of all four words is
> represented by a schwa. The difference in stress is shown by an accent, not by a
> different phonetic symbol. The word "abut", which Hugh recently mentioned in a
> post as needing "Up", rather than "Ado" for its second vowel is also listed with a
> schwa. Thus, I find no reason to suppose that Read somehow needlessly simplified
> Quikscript's ability to accurately represent English. And I have to respectfully
> disagree with you that these are separate and distinct sounds.
>
> > Ado and Up are distinct sounds as are Err and Array.
> > quickscript combines err and array which makes it harder to express
> > certain things, IMHO.
> >
> > Peace,
> > Star
> >
> > =====
> > "Having been unpopular in high school is not just cause for book publications."
> > -Frank Lebowitz
